trans-unit.source: Adding an Azure Active Directory by using Connected Services in Visual Studio | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Adding an Azure Active Directory by using Connected Services in Visual Studio | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Add an Azure Active Directory by using the Visual Studio Add Connected Services dialog box
trans-unit.target: Add an Azure Active Directory by using the Visual Studio Add Connected Services dialog box

trans-unit.source: Adding an Azure Active Directory by using Connected Services in Visual Studio
trans-unit.target: Adding an Azure Active Directory by using Connected Services in Visual Studio

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: By using Azure Active Directory (Azure AD), you can support Single Sign-On (SSO) for ASP.NET MVC web applications, or AD Authentication in Web API services.
trans-unit.target: By using Azure Active Directory (Azure AD), you can support Single Sign-On (SSO) for ASP.NET MVC web applications, or AD Authentication in Web API services.

trans-unit.source: With Azure AD Authentication, your users can use their accounts from Azure AD to connect to your web applications.
trans-unit.target: With Azure AD Authentication, your users can use their accounts from Azure AD to connect to your web applications.

trans-unit.source: The advantages of Azure AD Authentication with Web API include enhanced data security when exposing an API from a web application.
trans-unit.target: The advantages of Azure AD Authentication with Web API include enhanced data security when exposing an API from a web application.

trans-unit.source: With Azure AD, you do not have to manage a separate authentication system with its own account and user management.
trans-unit.target: With Azure AD, you do not have to manage a separate authentication system with its own account and user management.

trans-unit.source: Supported Project Types
trans-unit.target: Supported Project Types

trans-unit.source: You can use the Connected Services dialog to connect to Azure AD in the following project types.
trans-unit.target: You can use the Connected Services dialog to connect to Azure AD in the following project types.

trans-unit.source: ASP.NET MVC Projects
trans-unit.target: ASP.NET MVC Projects

trans-unit.source: ASP.NET Web API Projects
trans-unit.target: ASP.NET Web API Projects

trans-unit.source: Connect to Azure AD using the Connected Services dialog
trans-unit.target: Connect to Azure AD using the Connected Services dialog

trans-unit.source: Make sure you have an Azure account.
trans-unit.target: Make sure you have an Azure account.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have an Azure account, you can sign up for a <link><linkText>free trial</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you don't have an Azure account, you can sign up for a <link><linkText>free trial</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, open the shortcut menu of the References node in your project and choose Add Connected Services.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, open the shortcut menu of the References node in your project and choose Add Connected Services.

trans-unit.source: Select Azure AD Authentication and then choose Configure.
trans-unit.target: Select Azure AD Authentication and then choose Configure.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Choose Add Azure AD Authentication</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Choose Add Azure AD Authentication</linkText>

trans-unit.source: On the first page of the Configure Azure AD Authentication, check Configure Single Sign-on using Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: On the first page of the Configure Azure AD Authentication, check Configure Single Sign-on using Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: If your project is configured with another authentication configuration, the wizard warns you that continuing will disable the previous configuration.
trans-unit.target: If your project is configured with another authentication configuration, the wizard warns you that continuing will disable the previous configuration.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Configure Azure AD in the wizard</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Configure Azure AD in the wizard</linkText>

trans-unit.source: On the second page, select a domain from the Domain drop-down list.
trans-unit.target: On the second page, select a domain from the Domain drop-down list.

trans-unit.source: The list of domains contains all domains accessible by the accounts listed in the Account Settings dialog.
trans-unit.target: The list of domains contains all domains accessible by the accounts listed in the Account Settings dialog.

trans-unit.source: As an alternative, you can enter a domain name if you don’t find the one you’re looking for, such as mydomain.onmicrosoft.com.
trans-unit.target: As an alternative, you can enter a domain name if you don’t find the one you’re looking for, such as mydomain.onmicrosoft.com.

trans-unit.source: You can choose the option to create a new Azure AD app or use the settings from an existing Azure AD app.
trans-unit.target: You can choose the option to create a new Azure AD app or use the settings from an existing Azure AD app.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Configure Azure AD in the wizard</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Configure Azure AD in the wizard</linkText>

trans-unit.source: On the third page of the wizard, make sure that Read directory data is checked.
trans-unit.target: On the third page of the wizard, make sure that Read directory data is checked.

trans-unit.source: The wizard will fill in the Client secret.
trans-unit.target: The wizard will fill in the Client secret.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Configure Azure AD in the wizard</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Configure Azure AD in the wizard</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Choose the Finish button.
trans-unit.target: Choose the Finish button.

trans-unit.source: The dialog adds the necessary configuration code and references to enable your project for Azure AD authentication.
trans-unit.target: The dialog adds the necessary configuration code and references to enable your project for Azure AD authentication.

trans-unit.source: You can see the AD domain on the Azure portal.
trans-unit.target: You can see the AD domain on the Azure portal.

trans-unit.source: Review the Getting Started page that appears in your browser for ideas on next steps, and the What Happened page to see how your project was modified.
trans-unit.target: Review the Getting Started page that appears in your browser for ideas on next steps, and the What Happened page to see how your project was modified.

trans-unit.source: If you want to check that everything worked, open one of the modified configuration files and verify that the settings mentioned in What Happened are there.
trans-unit.target: If you want to check that everything worked, open one of the modified configuration files and verify that the settings mentioned in What Happened are there.

trans-unit.source: For example, the main web.config in an ASP.NET MVC project will have these settings added:
trans-unit.target: For example, the main web.config in an ASP.NET MVC project will have these settings added:

trans-unit.source: How your project is modified
trans-unit.target: How your project is modified

trans-unit.source: When you run the wizard, Visual Studio adds Azure AD and associated references to your project.
trans-unit.target: When you run the wizard, Visual Studio adds Azure AD and associated references to your project.

trans-unit.source: Configuration files and code files in your project are also modified to add support for Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: Configuration files and code files in your project are also modified to add support for Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: The specific modifications that Visual Studio makes depend on the project type.
trans-unit.target: The specific modifications that Visual Studio makes depend on the project type.

trans-unit.source: For detailed information about how ASP.NET MVC projects are modified, see <link><linkText>What happened– MVC Projects</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For detailed information about how ASP.NET MVC projects are modified, see <link><linkText>What happened– MVC Projects</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: For Web API projects, see <link><linkText>What happened – Web API Projects</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For Web API projects, see <link><linkText>What happened – Web API Projects</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.target: Ask questions and get help.
